instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
What are the troubleshooting steps for this one if it wont power on?

I took out the board, checked under scope, literally no water anywhere, no dents on the housing, so it seems laptop was properly used.

The small white LED is on when i connect the charger (i have an original apple charger usb-c), i can measure 8V on the battery connector when they are connected.

Fixed this model few times with new keyboard and new screen, but never measured the board before.

So what measurement will i report to you?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: also, i did not find donor board on aliexpress, only working boards for like 385eur (this is a 1.2ghz, 512gb ssd, 8gb ram model)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
Measure the power rails with the charger connected, battery disconnected. Which are present, which are missing?

I would start with <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>. Is this present? If not, what is its resistance to ground? If resistance to ground is below 350 ohms, does removing <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> remove the short circuit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85</SIGNAL> : 20v

 <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> : 3.265 v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: ppbus g3h : 8.6V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: The basics look good. Check all rails for shorts to GND. I had a few with a short on 5V rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
I came back finally to this one no shorts on any rails 
 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V 
line is not shorted to GND 
led is glowing a bit but laptop didn't take any current/charge, and doesn't turn on 
connected to power supply on battery connectors takes 0,10A nothing heating up.
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> replaced 
<CHIP>U4700</CHIP> replaced 
no luck still not working 
Any ideas ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> has firmware.
New chip will not work, you need one from donor board (same model).

Do you get voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with new chip???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> present on F7140 I measured 8.05V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
8.05V is not correct value for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I suppose you checked it without battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: I have connected power supply to battery connector. Should I put back <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> ? I have another donor board with have faulty CPU, well CPU  only is heating up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
"I have connected power supply to battery connector."
I'm not sure if I correctly understood you...
Did you connect bench power supply to battery connector, why?

You've got 8.6V with original <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Did you change it in base of which reason?
Didn't measure more signals on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
Because is easier to measure both board sides with power supply, would I will getting not right measurements with power supply ? 
I replace ic to try maybe it will resolved issue, this was common issue so I tried replace it.  
I didn't measure anything more so far.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
These new boards will not start untill SMC talks with the charger...
And never change components before some measurment indicates that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: Problem is that the laptop is not taking charge no current taken,  on old or new ic, so SMC is not talks witch charger and this <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is responsible for a charging as I can see on schematic

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message: <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> will not charge the battery, nor generate correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> untill SMC will permit that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
I put back <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> from donor board <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is back to normal 8.6V 
laptop still doesn't turn on.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> =0V 
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4W</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P5VOUT_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present 
I reflow SMC but no changes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Check if any pulse at least.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
I check voltages that you said

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.5v no pulses

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0 = 0v no pules 

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 3v3 no pulses 

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0 no pulses 

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3v26 going down to 0.3v when power button pressed

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 1.22v no changes when pressing power button

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.5v
-------------
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 3v3"
Are you sure?
High level for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> means the board already achieved S5 state and goes to S4; but you are missing a basic S5 voltage!
Check resistance to ground at L7560.
You could have a problem with <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
resistance on L7560 455 ohm 
double checked <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
I checked on TP first  but looks like board view is a bit different than the actual main board and test point wasn't for this signal

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 1.22v"
It has strong pull up resistor (1K) to <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
Remove <RESISTOR>R1405</RESISTOR> and check its level again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
resistor removed still no changes on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is still on 0.5v level no changes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
Still 1.22V at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>?
Looks like PCH issue; it should have a weak pull-up resistor inside.

Do you get <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> wont turn on at all, not water damaged
threads.message:
yes <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> have no changes I checked once more 
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> = 3v

threads.message: Put good flux and heat PCH untill 180-200 degrees; just to burn eventualy crap...
